evidence_span: The primary texture present after 1450 F (788 C) hot rolling to 0.140-in. and air annealing 30 min at 1450 F (788 C)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: There are twice as many basal poles in the transverse direction as in the normal direction (Fig. 4)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: After air annealing for 30 min at 1450 F, there are still more [1010] poles than [1120] poles in the rolling direction

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Metallographic observation substantiated that the material was not fully recrystallized

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: cold rolling increased the intensity of basal poles in the normal direction and in a direction 25 to 30 deg from the normal toward the transverse direction

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: the integrated intensity of basal poles within 25 to 30 deg of the normal direction is several times the integrated intensity within 25 to 30 deg of the transverse direction

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Alpha annealing causes the lattice to rotate approximately 30 deg about the basal pole to bring [1120] parallel to the rolling direction

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: The volume percentage of material that is rotated depends on the time and temperature of the anneal, longer times and higher temperatures bringing about the rotation of more material

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Schedule A calls for rolling and annealing at 1450 F (788 C), and Schedule B calls for rolling and annealing at 1550 F (843 C)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Schedule A calls for rolling and annealing at 1450 F (788 C), and Schedule B calls for rolling and annealing at 1550 F (843 C)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: the material rolled at the higher temperature has a far greater concentration of basal poles in the transverse direction than does the material rolled at 1450 F

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: tension tests were conducted in the longitudinal and transverse directions on the material from both lots

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: considerably greater mechanical anisotropy is present in the material rolled at the higher temperature

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Ultimate tensile strength, not shown here, showed less than half the anisotropy indicated by yield strength

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Intermetallic phases identified as ZrMo2 and ZrCu have been reported in this alloy

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: the quantity of intermetallic phases, ZrMo2 and Zr2Cu, as identified by X-ray diffraction, was fairly large in the hot-rolled material

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk3
evidence_span: Material broken down at a higher temperature, such as was used with Schedule B material, could be expected to show more massive intermetallic phases

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk3
evidence_span: the degree of anisotropy in this alloy seems to be related to the breakdown temperature in the same way as is the size of the second phase

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk3
evidence_span: this phase was detected in 0.75-in. thick material which was preheated to $1 8 0 0 \ : \mathrm { F } \left( 9 8 3 \ : \mathrm { C } \right)$ and rolled to 0.140-in. thickness under processing Schedule C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk3

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_010_chunk3
